newsitem.title: USA: Living Centers, GranCare set $1.8 billion merger.
newsitem.headline: Living Centers, GranCare set $1.8 billion merger.

text.p: Living Centres of America Inc. and Grancare Inc. said Thursday they agreed to a $1.8 billion merger that will create the second largest long-term care provider in the United States.
Houston-based Living Centres, which provides health care services to senior citizens, said in March that it was exploring a possible sale, merger or other venture to bolster its competitive position.
Grancare, based in Atlanta, offers specialised medical and long-term care services.
Living Centres and Grancare are moderately sized nursing home companies that analysts have said would probably need to find merger partners to survive as the industry consolidates.

News of the deal comes a day after Vencor Inc., a long-term care company based in Louisville, Ky., launched a tender offer worth about $640 million for Transitional Hospital Corp., which has agreed to a $565 million takeover offer from Select Medical Corp.
Vencor, which operates hospitals, nursing centres and other facilities, in March acquired Georgia-based Theratx Inc. in a deal worth $550 million.
Nursing home chains are trying to merge because of growing competition and cost pressures because of managed care.

The merger of Living Centres and Grancare will form a company with 330 facilities with 38,000 beds in 21 states providing long-term care, drug and rehabilitation services, assisted living and speciality health services, the companies said.
Under the deal, Living Centres shareholders will receive $40.50 a share in cash for 93 percent of the outstanding Living Centre stock and retain the rest under a recapitalization plan.

As part of the recapitalization, investment group Apollo Management LP will invest $200 million and own 39.3 percent of the new company. GranCare shareholders will own 49.5 percent and Living Centres shareholders will own 11.2 percent.
High-profile Wall Street investor Leon Black is one of the investors in Apollo Management.
The stock of both companies rose after the deal was announced, with Living Centres up $1.25 to $37.75 and Grancare up $1 to $8.75, both in late trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The board of the combined company will include two directors from Living Centres, four from GranCare and four members named by Apollo. The new board will select a management team of executives from both companies.
Savings resulting from integrating the two companies would be about $30 million, the companies said.
The deals are subject to approval by regulators and shareholders of the two health care companies.
